blogSustainableFeeding.title: Sustainable Feeding Practices for Modern Indian Dairy Farms
blogSustainableFeeding.subtitle: Sustainability is not “expensive tech.” It is mostly: better fodder planning, lower wastage, improved rumen efficiency, cleaner water, and consistent SOPs.
blogSustainableFeeding.sectionCoreIdeaTitle: Core idea: make each kg of feed convert into milk (not waste)

coreIdea.b1: Plan fodder supply across seasons (mix of legume + non-legume).
coreIdea.b2: Reduce mould, dust, and spoilage—these reduce intake and raise disease risk.
coreIdea.b3: Balance roughage:concentrate to protect rumen and maintain milk fat.
coreIdea.b4: Keep water clean and always available.

yearRound.b1: Use a cropping calendar to ensure green fodder availability.
yearRound.b2: Keep dry fodder reserve for lean months.
yearRound.b3: Store fodder off the ground; protect from moisture.

silage.b1: Silage helps stabilize fodder availability and reduces spoilage losses.
silage.b2: Proper compaction and sealing is critical (air causes mould).
silage.b3: Introduce gradually; monitor intake and dung consistency.

precision.b1: Measure concentrates with a fixed mug/can (standardize per animal).
precision.b2: Adjust based on yield and body condition score (thin/ideal/fat).
precision.b3: Split concentrate into multiple feedings (3–4 parts/day) for high producers.
precision.b4: Avoid sudden changes; adapt over 7–10 days when possible.

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionWastageChecklistTitle: Wastage control checklist (biggest hidden money leak)

r1.c3: Use raised trough, correct height, smaller frequent servings

r2.c3: Keep dry, ventilated, away from moisture; FIFO rotation

r3.c3: Uniform chop size; avoid dustiness; wet lightly if needed

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionRumenFriendlyTitle: Rumen-friendly sustainability (more milk solids, less problems)

protect.b1: Adequate fibre for cud chewing and saliva buffering.
protect.b2: Stable feeding times (rumen microbes like routine).
protect.b3: Avoid over-grain feeding that can cause acidosis and low milk fat.

water.b1: Low water intake reduces dry matter intake → lower milk.
water.b2: Keep water points close to resting area and feeding area.
water.b3: Heat stress months: water access becomes even more critical.

blogSustainableFeeding.sectionWhatToDoTitle: What to do today / this week / this month

week.b1: Plan fodder requirement for next 2 weeks.
week.b3: Inspect storage for moisture and insects.

month.b1: Review milk yield trends and feed cost per litre.
month.b2: Work with vet/extension to adjust minerals and ration balance.

blogSustainableFeeding.verdantNote: Sustainability is a system: fodder planning + storage + routine + rumen health + water + minerals. Small improvements compound into big profit.

blogLivestockDiseases.title: Common Livestock Diseases Every Indian Dairy Farmer Should Track
blogLivestockDiseases.subtitle: This is a field-focused guide: what to watch, what to do first, what to record, and when to call the vet. Fast action saves milk, fertility, and lives.

section60sCheck.item1: Appetite + water intake: any sudden drop is a red flag.
section60sCheck.item2: Dung: very watery / very dry / blood / foul smell → note immediately.
section60sCheck.item3: Cud chewing: low rumination often means rumen trouble, pain, fever, or acidosis.
section60sCheck.item4: Body temperature if animal looks dull (normal range varies; fever is a major sign).
section60sCheck.item5: Milk: clots, watery milk, blood, bad smell → suspect mastitis.
section60sCheck.item6: Feet/legs: limping, swelling, foul hoof smell → lameness/foot rot.
section60sCheck.item7: Breathing: coughing, nasal discharge, laboured breathing → respiratory infection.

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionEmergencyTitle: Emergency signs — call a vet urgently

sectionEmergency.item1: Animal down and unable to stand; severe weakness or tremors.
sectionEmergency.item2: Severe bloat (left side distended), breathing difficulty.
sectionEmergency.item3: High fever with mouth lesions / excessive salivation (suspect infectious disease).
sectionEmergency.item4: Blood in milk with udder swelling and pain.
sectionEmergency.item5: Sudden deaths or multiple animals sick at once.

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionCommonGroupsTitle: Most common problem groups on Indian dairy farms

udderMilk.earlyClues: Clots, watery milk, hot painful udder
udderMilk.firstActions: Isolate milker; clean milking routine; strip test; call vet for treatment plan

digestiveRumen.earlyClues: Off-feed, less cud chewing, loose dung, belly distension
digestiveRumen.firstActions: Stop sudden concentrate; offer roughage; check water; vet if bloat/fever

feetLegs.earlyClues: Limping, swelling, foul smell, reduced walking
feetLegs.firstActions: Clean & dry flooring; hoof hygiene; vet for trimming/antibiotics if needed

reproduction.firstActions: Nutrition + minerals; heat detection; vet exam; manage transition period

skinVector.firstActions: Tick control; shed sanitation; vet for diagnosis

prevention.item1: Pre-dip (if used), clean and dry teats; always wipe with separate cloth/tissue per animal.
prevention.item2: Full hand milking/ proper machine settings (if machine). Avoid teat injuries.
prevention.item4: Keep bedding dry and clean; remove dung frequently.
prevention.item5: Identify chronic cases and milk them last.

suspected.item1: Check milk for clots/wateriness; compare quarters.
suspected.item2: Mark the animal; milk separately; don’t mix milk in bulk can.
suspected.item3: Record: date, quarter affected, fever yes/no, milk change.
suspected.item4: Call vet for correct therapy and withdrawal guidance.

bloat.title: Bloat risk reducers
bloat.item1: Avoid sudden lush legume-heavy grazing without adaptation.
bloat.item2: Provide dry roughage before turning out to lush fodder.
bloat.item4: Observe animals after diet change; early bloat acts fast.

acidosis.title: Acidosis risk reducers
acidosis.item1: Maintain adequate fibre (roughage) to support rumination and saliva buffering.
acidosis.item2: Split concentrates into multiple feedings rather than one heavy meal.
acidosis.item3: If milk fat suddenly drops + loose dung: suspect rumen imbalance.
acidosis.item4: Review ration with a nutritionist if high producers.

biosecurity.item1: Quarantine new animals (separate pen) before mixing with herd.
biosecurity.item2: Separate sick animals; dedicate bucket/rope for them.
biosecurity.item3: Footbath at entry (where possible) and regular shed disinfection.
biosecurity.item4: Control visitors, vehicles, and shared equipment between farms.
biosecurity.item5: Follow local vaccination schedule (ask your vet/department).

blogLivestockDiseases.sectionTodayWeekMonthTitle: What to do today / this week / this month

week.item1: Clean bedding + drainage; fix wet areas.

month.item1: Record conception/heat issues and consult vet if repeats.
month.item3: Evaluate mastitis repeat cases and milking hygiene SOP.

blogLivestockDiseases.noteText: This guide is educational. Exact diagnosis and medicine must be decided with a veterinarian, especially for infectious diseases and milk withdrawal rules.
